name: New York City
intro_vibe: The Concrete Jungle: Fast, loud, kind but not nice, and the only place where 4am pizza is a food group.

general_info.description: New York is a collection of five distinct boroughs, not just Manhattan. It rewards efficiency and punishes hesitation. It is gritty, glamorous, and relentless. The locals are 'kind' (they will help you carry a stroller up the stairs) but not 'nice' (they won't smile while doing it).

weather_breakdown.name: January
weather_breakdown.clothing: Heavy coat, thermal layers, waterproof boots

weather_breakdown.name: June
weather_breakdown.clothing: Summer clothes, light jacket for A/C

etiquette_tips: Efficiency is Respect: Moving fast is how New Yorkers show respect for other people's time. Don't stop in the middle of the sidewalk. Step to the side.
Kind, Not Nice: A New Yorker won't smile at you, but if you fall down the stairs, they will be the first to pick you up. Don't confuse speed with rudeness.
The Subway Swagger: Let people OFF the train before you get ON. Stand aside. If a car is empty in rush hour, DO NOT GET IN (it smells).
Tipping is Mandatory: 20% minimum at sit-down restaurants. $1/drink at bars. This is not optional; it is their wage.
Escalator Etiquette: Stand on the RIGHT, walk on the LEFT. Blocking the left side is a mortal sin.
Pizza Rules: Fold the slice. Never use a fork and knife unless you want to be ridiculed.
Eye Contact: We ignore each other to give privacy in a crowded city. It is a form of politeness, not coldness.

neighborhoods.name: West Village
neighborhoods.description: Brownstones, tree-lined streets, and celebrity sightings. It feels like a movie set (because it usually is). Great for wandering and brunch.

neighborhoods.name: Williamsburg
neighborhoods.description: Brooklyn's trendiest neighborhood. Waterfront parks, vintage shopping, breweries, and incredible skyline views of Manhattan.

neighborhoods.name: Astoria & LIC
neighborhoods.description: The heart of Queens. Incredible Greek and Middle Eastern food, beer gardens, and skyline views without the Manhattan price tag.

neighborhoods.name: Harlem
neighborhoods.description: A cultural capital. Historic brownstones, incredible soul food, jazz history, and a vibrant community energy.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
logistics.summary: How to survive the concrete jungle.
details: Times Square: Go once, take a photo, leave immediately. The food is terrible and overpriced. Locals avoid it like the plague.
The Bathroom Code: Public restrooms don't exist. Use hotel lobbies, department stores (Macy's), or buy a coffee at Starbucks to get the code.
Bodegas: These are corner stores. Use them for water, snacks, sandwiches, and ATM cash. They are the neighborhood lifeline.
Stairs Everywhere: The subway is old. Elevators are rare or broken. Be prepared to carry your luggage up many flights of stairs.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The Subway is the lifeline. Taxis are for rain.
details: Subway: Runs 24/7. Use OMNY (tap your credit card/phone) at the turnstile. No need to buy a MetroCard anymore.
Walking: You will walk 15,000+ steps a day. Wear comfortable shoes. Heels are for Uber rides only.
Yellow Cabs: Hail from the street. The light on top means they are available. Cheaper than Uber for short hops.
Ferry: The NYC Ferry costs the same as the subway and offers incredible views. Great for going to Brooklyn/Queens.

logistics.title: Safety & Scams
details: CD Guys: In Times Square, men will hand you a 'free' CD then demand money. Don't touch it. Keep walking.
Costumed Characters: Elmo/Spiderman in Times Square will demand cash for photos. They can get aggressive.
Empty Subway Cars: If one car is empty and the rest are full, DO NOT GET IN. It has a smell or no AC.
Phone Snatching: Don't stand near the subway doors holding your phone loosely.

must_eat.description: Thin crust, foldable, greasy cheese pizza. Joe's Pizza is the gold standard. 2 Bros is the budget standard. Eat it standing up on the sidewalk.
Different from a slice. Charred, crispy, sit-down pizza sold only by the whole pie. John's of Bleecker or Totonno's. Worth the wait.
Boiled then baked. Dense and chewy. Order an 'Everything with Scallion Cream Cheese'. Ess-a-Bagel or Russ & Daughters. Do not toast it if it's fresh.
The quintessential breakfast. 'Bacon-Egg-and-Cheese-on-a-Roll'. Get it at a bodega, not a restaurant. Salt, pepper, ketchup optional.
New York has incredible Chinese food. Go to Chinatown (Manhattan) or Flushing (Queens) for soup dumplings (XLB) and massive dim sum halls.
A tower of cured, smoked beef on rye bread with mustard. Katz's Deli is the legend. Pair it with a Matzo Ball Soup.
Street meat. Spiced chicken, yellow rice, white sauce (famous), and red sauce (very hot). The Halal Guys is the original, but neighborhood carts are often better.

items.description: The lungs of the city. Don't just stay at the entrance. Go deep to the Ramble or the Reservoir to escape the noise.
Brooklyn's masterpiece (designed by the same guys as Central Park, but they did this one better). Huge meadows, BBQs, and local vibes.
The best people-watching in the world. Musicians, chess players, students, and eccentrics. The heart of the Village.
The best view of the Manhattan skyline, right on the water. Walk across the bridge, then rest here on the lawn.
Better than the Empire State Building because you can actually SEE the Empire State Building from here.
Massive and overwhelming. Pick one section (e.g., Egyptian Temple of Dendur) and enjoy it. Don't try to see it all.
A tour through actual preserved immigrant apartments from the 1800s. A deeply moving look at real NY history.
